ground_truth: In a corner booth, four big Transit Authority police are having a meal together. Cheryl looks at his utensils. The manager comes over, gesturing to the table of police that he can handle it. All attention is on Melvin. Melvin looks at the police, sizes up the hopeless situation, and rises. Melvin, ever the sharp observer, looks from the cab to see slices of community life -- men in front of a bar, parents giving their child a ride on a mechanical horse outside a local store -- two young women discuss dating. Carol opens the door just as he arrives on her landing. She holds a container of ice, washcloths, and a thermometer. Melvin ignores the question, instead answering a charge he had imagined she might make. Spencer just stares at him. She closes the door in his face, then walks to her son and leads him back to his room. The camera moves toward mother and son sitting on the edge of Spencer's bed. She holds a digital thermometer to his ear. They both count down the seconds. As they settle in and drive off. As Carol enters the hospital. Verdell lies just inside the front door whimpering for Melvin. Jackie sits across from Simon's wheelchair. She has some index cards in her lap which she occasionally consults and shuffles. Simon forces his attention to Jackie as their conversation continues -- the dog is distressed. Verdell walks out on the terrace and looks off. He turns for. Verdell hides behind a chair. As Jackie looks at him then thumbs for a card, the woman is tall, attractive, etc. She nods, pissed, waves, and leaves. As Melvin waits, Zoe summons her moxie. The fan is jolted as the elevator doors open and close. A depleted, exhausted Carol approaches her home. She is suddenly wary. As Carol breaks into a run. As she bounds the stairs, comes to her apartment door, and jiggles with the keys, a strange prescient whimpering sound coming from her. As she enters the apartment, the worst confirmed, she moves down the narrow hallway, her innards squirting the same chemicals that drive elk on opening day of the hunting season. Beverly, Carol's mother, enters the room. She is ebullient which, if life allowed, would be her natural state. Bettes' reaction to her mother adds a saving grace. As we approach the doctor and Carol seated across from each other at a small table, Carol looks at her mother -- they share a laugh. Beverly has a hard time stopping. Simon practices walking using his cane. A tearstained Nora hugs him goodbye. Nora, holding her things, knocks on Melvin's door. Melvin opens the door. Nora is still sniffling.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: In a corner cubicle, four large Transit Authority officers are having a feast together. Cheryl observes his silverware. The manager approaches, gesturing to the group of officers that he can manage it. All focus is on Melvin. Melvin observes the officers, evaluates the desperate predicament, and stands. Melvin, ever the keen observer, gazes from the cab to see glimpses of community existence -- men in front of a tavern, parents giving their youngster a ride on a mechanical steed outside a neighborhood shop -- two young women discuss courting. Carol opens the entrance just as he arrives on her landing. She holds a container of ice, washcloths, and a thermometer. Melvin disregards the inquiry, instead responding to an accusation he had envisioned she might make. Spencer just gazes at him. She shuts the door in his face, then walks to her son and guides him back to his chamber. The camera advances toward mother and son sitting on the edge of Spencer's bed. She holds a digital thermometer to his ear. They both tally down the moments. As they settle in and drive away. As Carol enters the clinic. Verdell lies just inside the front entrance whimpering for Melvin. Jackie sits across from Simon's wheelchair. She has some index cards in her lap which she occasionally references and shuffles. Simon directs his focus to Jackie as their dialogue continues -- the hound is distressed. Verdell strolls out on the balcony and gazes off. He turns for. Verdell hides behind a chair. As Jackie observes him then thumbs for a card, the woman is tall, attractive, etc. She nods, irked, waves, and departs. As Melvin waits, Zoe summons her courage. The fan is jolted as the elevator doors open and close. A drained, fatigued Carol approaches her residence. She is suddenly wary. As Carol sprints. As she bounds the stairway, arrives at her apartment door, and jiggles with the keys, a strange foreboding whimpering noise coming from her. As she enters the apartment, the worst confirmed, she moves down the narrow corridor, her innards squirting the same chemicals that propel elk on opening day of the hunting season. Beverly, Carol's mother, enters the room. She is exuberant which, if existence allowed, would be her natural condition. Bettes' reaction to her mother adds a saving grace. As we approach the physician and Carol seated across from each other at a small table, Carol observes her mother -- they share a chuckle. Beverly has a hard time ceasing. Simon practices walking using his cane. A tearstained Nora embraces him farewell. Nora, holding her belongings, knocks on Melvin's entryway. Melvin opens the door. Nora is still sniffling.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: In a corner booth, a meal is being had by four big Transit Authority police officers together. The utensils are looked at by Cheryl. The table of police is gestured at by the manager, who indicates he can handle it. All attention is directed at Melvin. The police are looked at by Melvin, who sizes up the hopeless situation and rises. Ever the sharp observer, slices of community life are seen by Melvin from the cab -- men in front of a bar, parents giving their child a ride on a mechanical horse outside a local store -- a discussion about dating is had by two young women. The door is opened by Carol just as her landing is reached by him. A container of ice, washcloths, and a thermometer is held by her. The question is ignored by Melvin, who instead answers a charge he imagined she might make. A stare is given by Spencer to him. The door is closed in his face by her, then her son is walked with back to his room. The camera moves toward mother and son as they sit on the edge of Spencer's bed. A digital thermometer is held to his ear by her. The seconds are counted down by them both. They settle in and drive off. The hospital is entered by Carol. Verdell lies just inside the front door, whimpering for Melvin. Jackie sits across from Simon's wheelchair. Some index cards are in her lap, which she occasionally consults and shuffles. Simon forces his attention to their conversation with Jackie -- the dog appears distressed. The terrace is walked out on by Verdell, who looks off before turning. Verdell is hidden behind a chair. As Jackie looks at him and thumbs for a card, the woman is tall, attractive, etc. She nods, pissed, waves, and leaves. As Melvin waits, her moxie is summoned by Zoe. The elevator doors are jolted open and closed by the fan. A depleted, exhausted Carol approaches her home. Wary she suddenly becomes. A run is broken into by Carol. The stairs are bounded by her, comes to her apartment door, and a jiggling with the keys is done; a strange prescient whimpering sound comes from her. As the apartment is entered by her, the worst confirmed, she moves down the narrow hallway, her innards squirting the same chemicals that drive elk on opening day of the hunting season. Beverly, Carol's mother, enters the room. Ebullience is shown by her, which, if life allowed, would be her natural state. A saving grace is added by Bettes' reaction to her mother. The doctor and Carol are approached as they sit across from each other at a small table, her mother is looked at by Carol -- they share a laugh. Beverly has a hard time stopping. Practicing walking using his cane is done by Simon. A tearstained Nora hugs him goodbye. Her things are held by Nora as she knocks on Melvin's door. The door is opened by Melvin. Sniffling is still done by Nora.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: In a corner booth, four Transit Authority police share a meal. Cheryl examines his utensils. The manager gestures to the police, indicating he can handle it. All eyes are on Melvin, who assesses the situation and stands. Observant Melvin sees slices of community life from the cab—men at a bar, parents with a child on a mechanical horse, and two women discussing dating. Carol opens the door as he arrives, holding ice, washcloths, and a thermometer. Melvin ignores a question, responding to an imagined charge. Spencer stares at him. She shuts the door, leads her son back to his room, and they sit on Spencer's bed, counting down seconds with a digital thermometer. As they drive off, Carol enters the hospital. Verdell whimpers for Melvin inside the front door. Jackie sits across from Simon's wheelchair, consulting index cards. Simon focuses on Jackie as they talk—the dog is distressed. Verdell hides behind a chair. Jackie looks at him, thumbs a card, and a tall, attractive woman nods, waves, and leaves. Melvin waits as Zoe gathers her courage. The fan jolts as elevator doors open and close. An exhausted Carol approaches home, suddenly wary. She runs up the stairs, fumbles with keys, and hears a prescient whimper. Entering the apartment, her worst fears are confirmed, her body reacting like elk on hunting season's opening day. Carol's mother, Beverly, enters, naturally ebullient. Bettes' reaction to her mother adds grace. At a small table, Carol and the doctor share a laugh. Beverly struggles to stop. Simon practices walking with a cane. A tearful Nora hugs him goodbye, then knocks on Melvin's door. Melvin opens it to a still-sniffling Nora.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: In a corner booth, four Transit Authority police eat together. Cheryl examines his utensils. The manager gestures to the police, indicating he can handle it. All eyes are on Melvin, who assesses the situation and stands. Melvin observes community life from the cab—men at a bar, parents with a child on a mechanical horse, and two women discussing dating. Carol opens the door as he arrives, holding ice, washcloths, and a thermometer. Melvin ignores a question, responding to an imagined charge. Spencer stares at him. She shuts the door, leads her son to his room, and they sit on Spencer's bed, counting down with a thermometer. As they drive off, Carol enters the hospital. Verdell whimpers for Melvin inside the door. Jackie sits across from Simon, consulting index cards. Simon focuses on Jackie as they talk—the dog is distressed. Verdell hides behind a chair. Jackie looks at him, thumbs a card, and leaves. Melvin waits as Zoe gathers courage. The fan jolts as elevator doors open and close. An exhausted Carol approaches home, wary. She runs, reaches her door, and hears a strange whimper. Entering, her worst fears are confirmed. Beverly, Carol's mother, enters, naturally ebullient. Bettes' reaction to her mother adds grace. Carol and her mother share a laugh with the doctor. Simon practices walking with a cane. A tearful Nora hugs him goodbye, then knocks on Melvin's door. Melvin opens it, and Nora is still sniffling.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: In a cozy corner booth of the bustling diner, four large Transit Authority police officers are gathered together, enjoying a meal. Cheryl, with a curious glance, examines his utensils. The attentive manager approaches, gesturing towards the table of officers to indicate that he can manage the situation. All eyes are focused intently on Melvin. Melvin, always the keen observer, assesses the police officers, evaluates the seemingly hopeless situation, and then stands up. Ever perceptive, Melvin looks out from the cab, observing slices of community life unfolding around him—men gathered in front of a lively bar, parents giving their child a joyful ride on a mechanical horse outside a quaint local store, and two young women animatedly discussing their dating lives. Just as Melvin arrives at her landing, Carol opens the door, holding a container filled with ice, washcloths, and a thermometer. Ignoring the question posed to him, Melvin instead responds to a charge he had imagined she might make. Spencer simply stares at him in silence. She closes the door in his face, then gently guides her son back to his room. The camera moves in closer to capture the tender moment between mother and son as they sit together on the edge of Spencer's bed. She carefully holds a digital thermometer to his ear, and they both count down the seconds together. As they settle into the car and drive away, Carol enters the hospital. Verdell, the dog, lies just inside the front door, whimpering for Melvin. Jackie sits across from Simon, who is in his wheelchair. She has a stack of index cards in her lap, which she occasionally consults and shuffles through. Simon forces himself to focus on Jackie as their conversation continues, despite the dog's distress. Verdell walks out onto the terrace, gazing off into the distance. He turns back and hides behind a chair. As Jackie looks at him and thumbs through a card, the woman, tall and attractive, nods, clearly annoyed, waves, and leaves. As Melvin waits, Zoe gathers her courage. The fan is jolted as the elevator doors open and close. A depleted and exhausted Carol approaches her home, suddenly feeling wary. As Carol breaks into a run, she bounds up the stairs, reaches her apartment door, and fumbles with the keys, a strange, prescient whimpering sound escaping from her. As she enters the apartment, her worst fears are confirmed. She moves down the narrow hallway, her insides churning with the same chemicals that drive elk on the opening day of hunting season. Beverly, Carol's mother, enters the room, her natural ebullience shining through, which, if life allowed, would be her constant state. Bettes' reaction to her mother adds a touch of saving grace. As we approach the doctor and Carol seated across from each other at a small table, Carol looks at her mother, and they share a heartfelt laugh. Beverly finds it difficult to stop laughing. Simon practices walking with the aid of his cane. A tear-stained Nora hugs him goodbye. Holding her belongings, Nora knocks on Melvin's door. Melvin opens the door to find Nora still sniffling.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: In a snug and inviting corner booth of the lively, bustling diner, four large Transit Authority police officers are gathered together, enjoying their hearty meal with camaraderie. Cheryl, casting a curious and attentive glance, examines his utensils with interest. The watchful and attentive manager approaches confidently, gesturing amicably in the direction of the table where the officers are seated, indicating through this gesture that he is fully capable of managing the situation if necessary. All eyes in the diner are focused intently on Melvin. Melvin, perpetually the keen observer with a sharp eye, assesses the group of police officers, carefully evaluating the seemingly hopeless situation before he decisively makes up his mind to stand up. Always perceptive, Melvin looks out from the cab, his gaze wandering as he observes the slices of community life unfolding around him—men gathered lively in front of a bustling bar, parents joyfully giving their child a delightful ride on a mechanical horse outside a quaint and charming local store, and two young women animatedly engrossed in discussing their vibrant dating lives. As timing would have it, just as Melvin arrives at her landing, Carol opens the door, holding a container filled with ice, washcloths, and a trusty thermometer. Ignoring an unspoken question, Melvin directs his response instead to a charge he had imagined she might make. Spencer simply stares at him in silence, unyielding. She then closes the door in his face, and with gentle guidance, leads her son back to his room. The camera moves in closer, capturing the tender and intimate moment between mother and son as they sit affectionately together on the edge of Spencer's bed. She carefully holds a digital thermometer to his ear, and together they count down the seconds in unison. As they settle into the car and drive away, Carol enters the hospital with determination. Verdell, the dog, lies just inside the front door, emitting a soft whimpering sound, yearning for Melvin's presence. Jackie sits across from Simon, who is positioned in his wheelchair. She holds a stack of index cards in her lap, which she occasionally consults and shuffles through out of habit. Simon forces himself to focus his attention on Jackie as their conversation continues, despite the distraction caused by the dog's distress. Verdell walks deliberately out onto the terrace, gazing off into the distance with curiosity. He then turns back and hides behind a chair, perhaps seeking comfort. As Jackie glances at him and thumbs through a card, a tall and attractive woman nods, clearly annoyed, waves dismissively, and leaves. As Melvin waits in anticipation, Zoe gathers her courage. The fan is abruptly jolted as the elevator doors open and close. A depleted and exhausted Carol approaches her home, suddenly feeling a sense of wariness. Breaking into a sudden run, Carol bounds up the stairs, reaches her apartment door, and fumbles urgently with the keys, a strange, prescient whimpering sound escaping involuntarily from her. Upon entering the apartment, her worst fears are confirmed. She moves swiftly down the narrow hallway, her insides churning with the same chemicals that instinctively drive elk on the opening day of hunting season. Beverly, Carol's mother, enters the room, her natural ebullience and vibrant energy shining through, which, in a perfect world, would be her constant state. Bettes' reaction to her mother adds a touch of saving grace and levity. As we draw closer to the doctor and Carol seated across from each other at a small, intimate table, Carol looks affectionately at her mother, and they share a heartfelt and relieving laugh. Beverly finds it hard to contain her laughter, which bubbles over. Meanwhile, Simon practices walking with the aid of his cane. A tear-stained Nora hugs him goodbye with emotion. Carrying her belongings, Nora knocks tentatively on Melvin's door. Melvin opens the door to find Nora still sniffling, her emotions clearly visible.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: In a corner booth, four large Transit Authority police officers are seated together, enjoying a meal. Cheryl, seated nearby, glances down at his utensils, contemplating them for a moment. The manager approaches their table, gesturing towards the group of police officers to indicate that he is capable of handling the situation. All eyes shift towards Melvin, who, feeling the weight of their attention, assesses the situation and realizes its futility. He then stands up, his mind racing with observations. As Melvin peers out from the cab, he takes in the vibrant slices of community life unfolding around him: men gathered in front of a bar, parents joyfully giving their child a ride on a mechanical horse stationed outside a local store, and two young women engaged in a lively discussion about dating. Meanwhile, Carol opens the door just as Melvin arrives at her landing, holding a container filled with ice, washcloths, and a thermometer. Melvin, choosing to ignore the question posed to him, instead responds to an accusation he imagines she might make. Spencer simply stares at him, unresponsive. Carol then closes the door in Melvin's face and walks over to her son, gently leading him back to his room. The camera follows them as they sit together on the edge of Spencer's bed, where Carol carefully places a digital thermometer in his ear, and they both count down the seconds together. As they settle in, the scene shifts to them driving off. Carol enters the hospital, while Verdell, the dog, lies just inside the front door, whimpering for Melvin. Jackie sits across from Simon, who is in a wheelchair, with a stack of index cards in her lap that she occasionally consults and shuffles through. Simon, despite his distraction, forces himself to focus on Jackie as their conversation continues, while Verdell, visibly distressed, walks out onto the terrace and gazes into the distance before turning back and hiding behind a chair. Jackie glances at him, then thumbs through her cards, while a tall, attractive woman nods, visibly annoyed, waves, and departs. As Melvin waits, Zoe gathers her courage. The fan is jolted as the elevator doors open and close. A weary and exhausted Carol approaches her home, suddenly feeling a sense of unease. She breaks into a run, bounding up the stairs, reaching her apartment door, and fumbling with her keys, a strange, prescient whimpering sound escaping from her. Upon entering the apartment, her worst fears are confirmed, and she moves down the narrow hallway, her body reacting with the same adrenaline rush that drives elk on the opening day of hunting season. Beverly, Carol's mother, enters the room, her natural ebullience shining through, which would be her default state if life permitted. Bettes' reaction to her mother adds a touch of grace to the moment. As we approach the doctor and Carol seated across from each other at a small table, Carol glances at her mother, and they share a laugh, with Beverly finding it difficult to stop. Meanwhile, Simon practices walking with the aid of his cane, and a tearstained Nora embraces him in a heartfelt goodbye. Holding her belongings, Nora knocks on Melvin's door, and when Melvin opens it, she is still sniffling, her emotions raw and visible.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: In a corner booth, four Transit Authority police officers share a meal. Cheryl examines his utensils as the manager approaches, signaling he can manage the situation. All eyes are on Melvin, who assesses the situation and stands up. Observant as ever, Melvin notices slices of community life from the cab: men outside a bar, parents with a child on a mechanical horse, and two young women discussing dating. Carol opens the door just as Melvin arrives, carrying ice, washcloths, and a thermometer. Ignoring her question, Melvin responds to an imagined accusation. Spencer stares at him as Carol closes the door, then leads her son back to his room. The camera follows them to Spencer's bed, where they use a digital thermometer together. As they settle in and drive off, Carol enters the hospital. Verdell, the dog, whimpers for Melvin inside the front door. Jackie sits across from Simon in his wheelchair, consulting index cards during their conversation. Verdell, distressed, hides behind a chair as Jackie interacts with him. A tall, attractive woman nods, waves, and leaves. As Melvin waits, Zoe gathers her courage. The elevator doors open and close, jostling the fan. An exhausted Carol approaches her home, suddenly wary. She breaks into a run, bounds up the stairs, and fumbles with her keys at the apartment door, emitting a prescient whimper. Entering, her worst fears are confirmed as she moves down the hallway, driven by adrenaline. Beverly, Carol's mother, enters the room, naturally ebullient. Carol's reaction to her mother adds a saving grace. At a small table, Carol and the doctor share a laugh, Beverly struggling to stop. Simon practices walking with his cane as a tearful Nora hugs him goodbye. Holding her belongings, Nora knocks on Melvin's door, which he opens to find her still sniffling.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: In a corner booth, four big Transit Authority police, who are tasked with ensuring the safety of public transportation systems, are having a meal together. Cheryl looks at his utensils, noticing their slight misalignment. The manager, an experienced handler of stressful situations, comes over, gesturing to the table of police that he can handle it. All attention is on Melvin. Melvin, aware of the impact his actions can have, looks at the police, sizes up the hopeless situation, and rises. Melvin, ever the sharp observer, looks from the cab to see slices of community life—a group of men in front of a local bar known for its lively atmosphere, parents giving their child a ride on a mechanical horse outside a neighborhood store reminiscent of mid-century Americana—two young women discuss dating trends in the digital age. Carol opens the door just as he arrives on her landing. She holds a container of ice, washcloths for fever relief, and a thermometer. Melvin ignores the question, instead answering a charge he had imagined she might make, showcasing his often misunderstood introspective nature. Spencer just stares at him. She closes the door in his face, then walks to her son and leads him back to his room, a serene escape decorated in soothing blue tones. The camera moves toward mother and son sitting on the edge of Spencer's bed. She holds a digital thermometer to his ear, a tool known for its accuracy and speed. They both count down the seconds. As they settle in and drive off, as Carol enters the bustling hospital, Verdell lies just inside the front door whimpering for Melvin, his loyalty unwavering. Jackie sits across from Simon's wheelchair, which has been customized for his comfort. She has some index cards in her lap which she occasionally consults and shuffles. Simon forces his attention to Jackie as their conversation continues—the dog is distressed. Verdell walks out on the terrace and looks off, an action indicating his longing. He turns for shelter. Verdell hides behind a chair, feeling vulnerable yet seeking protection. As Jackie looks at him then thumbs for a card, the woman is tall, attractive, describes her confident demeanor. She nods, pissed, waves, and leaves. As Melvin waits, Zoe summons her moxie, an inner strength that has served her well in past challenges. The fan is jolted as the elevator doors open and close, a reminder of the constant comings and goings of city life. A depleted, exhausted Carol approaches her home. She is suddenly wary, realizing something feels off. As Carol breaks into a run, as she bounds the stairs, comes to her apartment door, and jiggles with the keys, a strange prescient whimpering sound coming from her, instinctively knowing something is wrong. As she enters the apartment, the worst confirmed, she moves down the narrow hallway, her innards squirting the same chemicals that drive elk on opening day of the hunting season, a primal reaction of fight or flight. Beverly, Carol's mother, enters the room. She is ebullient which, if life allowed, would be her natural state, always the optimist. Bettes' reaction to her mother adds a saving grace, a touch of humor to a tense moment. As we approach the doctor and Carol seated across from each other at a small table, Carol looks at her mother—they share a laugh, a momentary relief from the pressures of reality. Beverly has a hard time stopping, her laughter infectious. Simon practices walking using his cane, a testament to his resilience. A tearstained Nora hugs him goodbye, her embrace filled with unspoken words. Nora, holding her things tightly as if to keep herself grounded, knocks on Melvin's door. Melvin opens the door. Nora is still sniffling, trying to hold back the flood of emotions that has overwhelmed her.

She holds a digital thermometer to his ear. They both count down the seconds As they settle in and drive off. As Carol enters the hospital Verdell lies just inside the front door whimpering for Melvin. Jackie sits across from Simon's wheelchair. She has some index cards in her lap which she occasionally consults and shuffles. Simon forces his attention to Jackie as their conversation continues. the dog is distressed. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: In a secluded cabin, four large Forest Rangers are enjoying a picnic together. Bryce examines his binoculars. The groundskeeper approaches, pointing at the picnic of rangers that he can manage it. All eyes are on Greg. Greg observes the rangers, assesses the fruitless predicament, and stands. Greg, always the keen detective, peers from the car to spot glimpses of rural existence -- women outside a cafe, siblings giving their pet a spin on a merry-go-round in front of a neighborhood market -- two young men debate traveling. Alice unlocks the gate just as he arrives on her porch. She carries a basket of apples, sponges, and a ruler. Greg dismisses the inquiry, instead responding to an accusation he fancied she could lodge. Alex just glares at him. She shuts the gate in his face, then strolls to her daughter and guides her back to her garden. The lens pans toward mother and daughter lounging on the edge of Alex's patio. She presses a solar panel to her nose. They both tally up the minutes. As they recline in and sail away. As Alice steps into the museum. Duffy snoozes just under the porch swing whining for Greg. Jamie lounges opposite from Oliver's tricycle. She holds some coupons in her purse which she occasionally reads and rearranges. Oliver diverts his focus to Jamie as their chat persists -- the cat is uneasy. Duffy trots out onto the balcony and gazes around. He swivels for. Duffy nestles behind a tree. As Jamie glances at him then gestures for a coupon, the gentleman is short, charming, etc. She shrugs, frustrated, salutes, and exits. As Greg lingers, Mia gathers her courage. The breeze is startled as the stairwell doors swing and shut. A drained, fatigued Alice nears her abode. She is abruptly cautious. As Alice bursts into a sprint. As she leaps the steps, reaches her cottage entrance, and fumbles with the locks, a peculiar foreboding howling emanating from her. As she steps into the cottage, the worst confirmed, she proceeds down the slender corridor, her insides spurting the same enzymes that propel wolves on the first day of spring migration. Margaret, Alice's cousin, strides into the space. She is jubilant which, if destiny permitted, would be her default mode. Clara's reaction to her cousin adds a redeeming quality. As we draw near the chef and Alice seated opposite each other at a small counter, Alice glances at her cousin -- they share a joke. Margaret struggles to cease laughing. Oliver rehearses skipping using his umbrella. A tearful Emma embraces him farewell. Emma, clutching her packages, taps on Greg's window. Greg cracks open the window. Emma is still sobbing.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: In a corner booth, four Transit Authority police eat together while Melvin, an observant observer, assesses the situation and rises. From his cab, Melvin glimpses community scenes, such as men outside a bar and parents with a child on a mechanical horse. Carol arrives at home with medical supplies and tends to her son Spencer, who is sick in bed. The camera follows the mother and son as they check his temperature. At the hospital, Carol feels wary and anxious as she enters her apartment. Her mother, Beverly, usually cheerful, joins her at the doctor’s office where they share a laugh. Meanwhile, Simon practices walking with a cane as Nora, tearful, knocks on Melvin’s door, which he opens.
